Award.AwardTitle: Algebraic groups, arithmetic subgroups and geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many geometric and arithmetic objects have symmetries that can be encoded in the mathematical notion of a group. Often such groups possess additional structure, forming what is known as an algebraic group. The PI plans to work on several research projects related to algebraic groups and their internal structure, as well as their associated geometric and arithmetic objects, especially symmetric spaces. In addition the PI plans to write three books during the duration of this award.

Recent research of the PI includes work with Brian Conrad and Ofer Gabber on the classification of pseudo-reductive algebraic groups, with Andrei Rapinchuk on arithmetically defined locally symmetric spaces, and with Sai-Kee Yeung in complex algebraic geometry. Under this award the PI proposes to investigate new directions related to these collaborations. He will also continue his work on the congruence subgroup problem and the Margulis-Platonov conjecture (the latter gives a description of the normal subgroups of the group of rational points of a simply-connected semi-simple group defined over a global field). In another direction, the PI has associated a Levi subgroup to any irreducible admissible representation of a reductive p-adic group. He proposes to investigate the role of this Levi subgroup in the construction and classification of representations. The three books the PI plans to write are one on the Bruhat-Tits theory of reductive groups over nonarchimedean local fields, one on Lie groups based on his graduate courses at the University of Michigan, and one, jointly with Andrei Rapinchuk, on the congruence subgroup problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I have given a new approach to unramified and tamely ramified descent in Bruhat-Tits theory of reductive p-adic groups. Bruhat-Tits theory has two parts. The first part is the theory over the maximal unramified extension, this part is relatively simple and is essentially due to Iwahori, Matsumoto and Hijikata. The second part is quite difficult and it provides the descent from the maximal unramified extension to the ground field. As Bruhat-Tits theory is increasingly being used in geometry, number theory, representation theory and harmonic analysis, it is important to learn the theory. The new approach to descent given in my two recent papers is more geometric and considerably simpler than the original approach of Bruhat and Tits. So the new approach will help graduate students and other mathematicians to learn Bruhat-Tits theory and use it in their research.
In a joint work with Brian Conrad, that has been published as a monograph by Princeton University Press, we have classified pseudo-reductive groups over fields of arbitrary characteristic. This classification is especially difficult over fields of characteristic 2 since over such fields there are a lot more pseudo-reductive groups. The structure of pseudo-reductive groups (determined in my earlier joint work with Brian Conrad and Ofer Gabber) and classification of such groups is an important and useful contribution to the theory of algebraic groups. The structure and classification of pseudo-reductive groups is being used by various mathematicians working in algebraic geometry, number theory and arithmetic of algebraic groups.
Zariski-dense subgroups of semi-simple groups atise in many geometric and number theoretic contexts. So it is important to learn wht kind of elements can they contain. For example do they always contain elements called generic elements which have some very special properties. In my joint work with Andrei Rapinchuk, over fields of positive characteristic we have proved that any Zariski-dense subgroup of semi-simple group that contains an element of infinite orders does always contain a geneic elements. We had proved earlier that  over fields of characteristic zero, every Zariski-dense subgroup contains a generic element. We have also proved a rather surprising result that the subset of generic elements is quite large, it is open in the pro-finite topology. These results have been proven using number theoretic tools and are being used in differential geometry.
